author: Shiv Sahay Singh
text:
After blocking the railway tracks in the Alipurduar Division for over 48 hours, a breakthrough may be finally in sight with the protesters demanding separate state of Cooch Behar agreeing to sent a memorandum to Union Home Ministry through the district administration.

However, the question remains as to how could hundreds of protesters under the banner of Greater Cooch Behar Peoples Association (GCPA) paralysed train services in north Bengal and Assam for over two days.

On Monday, there was also a blockade at Kokrajhar district of Assam over host of demands but it was lifted after the District Magistrate met the protesters.

At New Cooch Behar railway station where hundreds are squatting on the railway tracks since the morning of February 20 it was only late on Monday evening that a group of them visited the office of District Magistrate Cooch Behar to submit a deputation addressed to Union Home Minister Rajnath Singh.

“The Railway authorities kept saying that the blockade is an issue concerning the State and refused to talk while the District authorities said that our demands concerned the Centre so they did not act as proactively as they should,” said Banghsi Badan Baraman, general secretary of the GCPA told The Hindu .

Bhaskar Nandy, septuagenarian leader of CPI (M-L) said that movement for Greater Cooch Behar, which demands status of a C category state, or a Union Territory has lost the backing of people.
title: Railway blockade in Cooch Behar continues
